title: stuck in a carpark with no gears. need gear linkage advice

posts.content:
No gears and the gear stick is moving around freely. Looked under the bus and the rear linkage has come apart. I've never worked on the transmission so not sure how to get this back together and running. Stuck in a carpark near Rutland Water on a bank holiday weekend away

Anyone got any advice?

Is it the gear linkage that's pulled apart? If so can you cobble together a temporary connector, it should have something like one of these joining it.



Sent from my sofa.

author.location: Sunny Gosport on the South Coast

posts.content:
There's a diagram on the VW heritage site with how is should look ( not sure if it differs by year but you get the idea ).

https://www.vwheritage.com/shop/split-b ... selectors/

I guess you need to see where it has come disconnected number 7 or number 11. Maybe just one of your secrews ( number 8 ) has undone

Andy

What has likely happened is your rear connector has sheared.

It consists of two top hat shaped steel flanges connected with rubber.

If you can get the two sides lined up and close enough to each other, I have heard of people clamping a mole wrench around the perimeter to hold them together as a 'get you home' solution.

This of course assumes you have said pair or mole wrenches to hand.

It's worth considering that if the fix fails on the road, you'll be in a more dangerous location, so worth considering getting recovered from your current safe location.

Hope this helps and best of luck.

Nik

andy f wrote:I guess you need to see where it has come disconnected number 7 or number 11. Maybe just one of your secrews ( number 8 ) has undone

Thanks for the responses. It's the coupling (number 11) that has split into 2 parts, with each still connected to the rod (front) and the next section into the gearbox. If clamp these back together with mole grips then I regain a working gear shifter but there is no obvious way to bodge these together to allow me to dare drive home. There's no holes to pass a bolt or other fixing through. It looks like the 2 halves are bound together by some sort of plastic/rubber material that has failed over some time. Earlier today I was having trouble finding 2nd gear... It kept wanting to go into 4th instead. Before today I've had no other issues.

Anyway, I think the holiday has come to an abrupt end and a recovery vehicle is on its way. Glad I'm only 50 miles from home.

Cheers, Banger. Great of you to offer but we were only out for the bank hol weekend and today I'll be mostly driving back to Rutland in the car to collect the awning and camping gear.

carry cable ties , ive seen this issue fixed in this way and the guy drove it around for 3months before he pit a proper one om

Just seen this myself. I had the same problem not that long ago and did the cable ties around both ends and then ties linking the 2 parts together. It wasn't that good, it'd only let me get 2nd and 4th gear but I managed a 10 mile trip home then a 10 mile trip to the garage once I got the part.
As already said...better to be safe and call recovery

Cable ties would possibly have got me home but reckon I was best calling the recovery wagon.

I've now got a new rear coupling but there's not enough gap between the two rods to allow me to fit it. I need another 10mm and have the selector rod pushed into the gearbox (not sure what gear it clicked into) and gear stick back in 2nd/4th position to bring the rear shift rod as forward as possible. How can I increase the gap? Will removing the gear stick assembly and loosening the front shift rod allow it all to slide forward more? Surely I don't need to drop the engine and gearbox just to fit this coupling?
You need the gearbox to be in first or third, and then put the lever in second or fourth. That should give you enough gap.

stu(pid) wrote:You need the gearbox to be in first or third

How easy is it to find 1st or 3rd with no coupling? I wiggled it in as far as I though it would go with my mole grips and it felt like I'd selected a gear but not sure which

It's fairly easy to get it lined up, but pushing the shaft into the gearbox is difficult. Try and line it up using mole grips, hold the coupling in the right place, then get someone to push the lever forward to try and force the shaft in.
